definitions.definition: quick at learning and understanding things
definitions.labels: (especially British English)(especially North American English)especially British English

examples.text: a clever child
Clever girl!
He's **too clever by half**, if you ask me *(= it annoys me or makes me suspicious)*.
They're not clever enough to find the code.

phrases: too clever for your own good

definitions.definition: showing intelligence or skill, for example in the design of an object, in an idea or somebody’s actions
definitions.sensetop: it is clever of somebody to do somethingit is clever to do somethingclever of somebody

examples.text: a clever trick
What a clever idea!
That wasn't very clever *(= what you just did wasn't sensible)*, was it?
clever marketing
Admitting her mistake may have been quite a clever move on her part.
It was clever of him to have spotted the mistake.
examples.contextForm: it is clever of somebody to do something

examples.text: How clever of you to work it out!
'Young people think it's clever to do that sort of thing, and it isn't,' she said.

a simple yet fiendishly clever idea
a clever little gadget

definitions.definition: quick with words in a way that annoys people or does not show respect

examples.text: Don't you get clever with me!

phrases: too clever for your own good

definitions.definition: to act in a clever way to get what you want, sometimes tricking somebody

examples.text: Suzie realized that she had to box clever. She had to let Adam think she trusted him.

wordOrigin: Middle English (in the sense ‘quick to catch hold’, only recorded in this period): perhaps of Dutch or Low German origin, and related to cleave ‘to stick to something’. In the late 16th cent. the term came to mean (probably through dialect use) ‘manually skilful’; the sense ‘possessing mental agility’ dates from the early 18th cent.
